title: Duke Regional Vascular Access
description: Duke Regional Vascular Access Clinic provides vascular access services for patients in a convenient North Durham County location.
cleaned_text: Face masks are optional at this location. Keeping everyone safe and well is our top priority. We appreciate your support of our efforts. [Learn more](/experience-safe-care). Duke Regional Vascular Access Our specialists provide expert care for adults with problems related to their vascular system -- the network of vessels that transport blood and lymph fluid throughout the body. We provide the full spectrum of vascular-related care, beginning with an evaluation and through treatment, surgery consultation, and beyond. Clinic Hours |7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 5:00 27704-2726 Clinic - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||7:30 am - 5:00 pm||Closed||Closed| Services As part of a thorough evaluation, our vascular specialists will talk with you about your concerns and medical history, perform a physical exam, administer pulse volume recording (PVR) and ultrasound imaging if needed, order other needed tests, and create a treatment plan. Conditions we treat include: [Aneurysms](https://www.dukehealth.org/treatments/heart/aneurysm-and-aortic-disease?showMiniFAD=1&docsShowing=10)in the abdomen, legs, or arms [Carotid artery disease](https://www.dukehealth.org/treatments/vascular-disease/carotid-artery-disease) - Claudication (cramping during walking) - Dialysis access for [kidney failure](https://www.dukehealth.org/treatments/kidney-disease/dialysis) - Leg or arm blockages [Peripheral artery disease](https://www.dukehealth.org/treatments/vascular-disease/peripheral-vascular-disease-and-peripheral-arterial-disease) - Peripheral edema (fluid buildup or swelling in the legs or arms) [Varicose veins](https://www.dukehealth.org/treatments/vascular-disease/varicose-veins-and-venous-diseases) - Vein problems - Wound management and debridement Surgical Services We will help determine whether surgery is the best option for you. We may order imaging studies such as an ultrasound or CT scan, or refer you to other specialists to ensure surgery would be safe for you. We perform sclerotherapy in our office. Other surgeries are performed at [Duke Regional Hospital](https://www.dukehealth.org/hospitals/duke-regional-hospital), [Duke University Hospital](https://www.dukehealth.org/hospitals/duke-university-hospital), [Davis Ambulatory Surgical Center](https://www.dukehealth.org/locations/davis-ambulatory-surgical-center). After surgery, we'll schedule follow-up visits to check that your wounds are healing properly and that your treatment goals are being met. Our Providers Accepted Insurance Duke Health contracts with most major health insurance carriers and transplant networks, including the ones listed below. Before scheduling your appointment, we strongly recommend you contact your insurance company to verify that the Duke Health location or provider you plan to visit is included in your network. Your insurance company will also be able to inform you of any co-payments, co-insurances, or deductibles that will be your responsibility. If you proceed in scheduling an appointment and your health insurance benefits do not participate with Duke, your out of pocket liability may be higher. We will contact you regarding your coverage and patient liability. If you are uninsured, learn more about our [financial assistance policy](/health-insurance-and-billing/paying-for-your-care/financial-assistance).
